text:
>>> GREETINGS, STARFARER <<<

Welcome to the Nexerelin mod for Starsector!

Nexerelin is essentially a 4X extension to the game. Factions within the sector will wage war, create alliances and compete to control a greater share of the sector.

Nexerelin is compatible with a large number of community-made faction mods, which you can add for a more varied gameplay experience.

text:
Your actions will gain or lose you influence with the factions in the Sector. The higher your influence with a faction, the greater access to their support and technology you will have.

At the start of the game, you pick a faction to join. You are a representative of your chosen faction, and your actions in the Sector will reflect on them. 

You can move to another faction later, if you can earn their trust. You can also choose to go it alone and set up your own empire.
Have fun and please leave any feedback on the Starsector forums :)

text: One of the survivors' settlements on the surface is hailing your ship.
One of the survivors' settlements on the surface is hailing your ship. But with a hostile fleet nearby, it's probably not something you have time to deal with right now.
You open a comm link, your comms officer configuring the protocol to interface with whatever jury-rigged system the other party is using.

"Hello? Is this thing on?

"Oh, hello, stranger! It's been a long time since anyone swung by. Is the Sector still alive? Where'd you get that ship? Have they finally found where Ludd went?"

Maybe dropping off a datacube for $himOrHer to read at $hisOrHer own leisure would get $himOrHer to stop asking questions.
OR
"A ship! A ship, a ship, a ship!!

"Gods, are we glad to see you! For the longest time we were wondering if there was even anyone else alive out there. My name is $personName, and I can't wait to shake your hand!"

"Praise the gods! I was starting to fear we'd never see a ship in the sky again.

"As you can guess, we've had no contact with the rest of the Sector since... since the previous government fell and everything went to hell here."
OR
"A $shipOrFleet! I guess the Sector hasn't forgotten $marketName after all.

"Most of us are stuck here on $marketName, living day to day. It's a wonder most of us are even alive, honestly."

"Hello, space traveler! I see you decided to stop by again."
OR
"Oh, it's $playerName."
"You've come back...?"

"Now, we happen to be in need of some $nex_decivEvent_takeName. In return, we can give you some $nex_decivEvent_giveName. Interested?"
OR
"Let's make a trade, spacer. You give us $nex_decivEvent_takeName, in exchange for some $nex_decivEvent_giveName. How about that?"

"I've got an offer for you. We've got a decent stockpile of $nex_decivEvent_giveName, but not the refining facilities to process it. At the same time, we could use some $nex_decivEvent_takeName. Would you be interested in a trade?"

"Right, here's the deal. We happen to have a large stock of $nex_decivEvent_giveName — very valuable before the Collapse. But we lack the manufacturing industry needed to make use of them; here on $marketName, they're just shiny baubles. If you happen to have some $nex_decivEvent_takeName, we could make a trade."

"Now, listen here. I've got a load of prisoners captured in a recent raid. More than I want to feed, in truth. I suppose an enterprising spacefarer like yourself would have no trouble putting them to work on a starship. All I ask for in exchange is a little $nex_decivEvent_takeName."

Dealing in slaves — as this offer surely is — tends to be frowned on under most moral systems. On the other hand, the captives may be considerably better off on your $shipOrFleet than with... this person.

"Please help us, good starfarer. Me and my friends, we've been stranded on this world for... for far too long. A few more months here and we'll be dead, or worse.

Let us come aboard your $shipOrFleet. There are $nex_decivEvent_giveCount of us, all willing to work our passage off this place."
OR
"I beg you for a favor, $playerName. This place, $marketName, it's no place to live. Not with the total collapse of society, with every meal possibly our last, with packs of raiders and looters seizing everything — and everyone — they can get their hands on.

Please, take us away from this world. We'll work on your $shipOrFleet, all $nex_decivEvent_giveCount of us. We would be eternally grateful."

"Right, so there's something only you can help us with.

There's a nearby pack of knaves and scum that needs dealing with. We'd clear the whole rotten nest out ourselves, but alas, their defenses are a little too entrenched. You, on the other hand... with your spaceship, you could drop a few  bombs on them and blow them straight to hell. In return, we'll give you some $nex_decivEvent_giveName. Sounds good?"

$personName transmits several images and the coordinates of the target. With the rudimentary defenses present, you estimate that it'd take no more than $nex_decivEvent_takeCount fuel to completely destroy this settlement. Assuming, of course, that intervening in $marketName's conflicts is a good idea.

"Got any boys with fancy guns up there? If so, we have a little favor to ask.

"Recently, a rival camp stole something of great value to us,  $nex_decivEvent_raidItem. We'd go and get it back, but they're dug in too deep for us to handle. But if you were to come in with your fancy shuttles and power armor, they'd crumple like cellulose paper. In return, you can keep whatever other valuables you find in their miserable den. Interested?"

Do you risk your marines' lives, even against such meager opposition, for uncertain loot?

text:
"We have a great favor to ask of you, friend $playerName.

The people of $marketName desire to reach the stars once more. We've organized ourselves a stable polity here, and with just a little more assistance we could become a part of the Sector community once again. 

All we need is a little in the way of supplies and machinery. If you would be so generous as to provide these, we would be immensely grateful."

"Excellent! A pleasure doing business with you."

You cut the comm link after some pleasantries and dispatch a shuttle to the surface of $marketName to make the trade.

"That's a shame. Well, we'll be here if you change your mind."

You cut the comm link after exchanging some pleasantries.

"Thank you so much! We'll come abroad right away."

You cut the comm link and dispatch a shuttle to the surface of $marketName to pick up your new crewmembers. Hopefully they'll fit in well... and won't bring aboard some horrible new pox hitherto unknown to the Sector.

"You... have you no heart? You would truly leave us here?"

You swiftly cut the comm link. You don't need to hear any more of this.
OR
"No! Don't leave us!"

$personName's desperate pleas are cut off abruptly as you disconnect the link.

The jury-rigged antimatter bombs serve to obliterate the target most satisfyingly, leaving nothing but a patchwork of craters scarring the landscape.

$personName is most pleased. "Excellent!" $heOrShe crows. "Take your reward, friend. You've earned it."

A while later, your shuttle returns to your $shipOrFleet with the promised goods. That's one problem taken care of, at least.

"Bah, fine. Have it your way, Captain High-and-Mighty."

You cut the comm link. The outcome of whatever feud $personName and $hisOrHer neighbors have down there is none of your concern.

text: "What is this madness, heathen? If I could slay you in the name of Ludd right now, I would."
"You're already commissioned by $theOtherCommissionFaction. Our cause permits no conflicting loyalties; any who love others more than Ludd is unworthy of Him."
"You are not yet worthy to join us."

"Interesting. You may be worthy yet of our holy cause.

The way of the Path is a demanding one. Our godless enemies are many; you must not falter in fighting them wherever you find them, and spreading the word of Ludd to all in this dark sector.

Deviation from the cause is a grievous sin. Should you be so lost as to attempt any such thing, our brethren shall think nothing of slaying you as a traitor deserves."
"Shall you raise this sword with the blessings of Ludd?"
"Praise be to the spirit of the stars! I am blessed to be the first to welcome you to this righteous service."
"Greetings, dear sibling. Please do ask if there is anything I can do for you."

"So be it, then. We have no use for those too weak to face the path of righteousness.

Do you have anything else to say?"
"You speak of treason. Is your faith wavering? There is no way from the Path except in death or damnation."

"So be it, accursed one.

Depart now, before the hammer of righteous judgment finds you."
"We will not speak of this matter again. I expect penitence from you, sibling."
"Yeah, not gonna happen, buddy. You sure as hell ain't one of us."
"No can do. Stop flying the flag of $theOtherCommissionFaction and maybe we can talk."
"You ain't got our trust yet. It takes more than a fancy suit and a piece of paper to make a pirate, mate; it takes a real tough guy."

"So, you wanna fly the black flag eh? Sick of the rules and laws of petty tyrants?

Guess I should remind you that we're enemies of most of the Sector. Expect to be beset at every turn by those self-righteous pricks... but at the same time, there's plunder aplenty for those daring enough, and you get your share of the common booty."
"You up for the challenge, friend?"
"Th' boss will be pleased to hear it. Come on down to the bar and have a drink with us."
"Anything else ya need?"

"Yeah, not everyone has the balls to be a pirate. Guess you'll just have to be content with being the prey instead. Heh.

"Wanna go legit, eh? I can't stop ya, but some of the boys might get ideas now that yer ain't one of us any longer."

"Of course. Once you've tasted freedom, there ain't no going back. Now, ran into any vulnerable convoys lately?"

text:
$personLastName meets you at a table outside the restaurant. 

In contrast to his appearance on the comm not a day ago, the League $personRank before you now is a worn, hollowed-out imitation of a $manOrWoman. As if he was the one who'd been locked up with the interrogator.

"Hello, $playerFirstName," he says, wearily. "Please, order anything you like. It's my treat, after all."

The $personRank looks at you for a long while. "You didn't hear this from me, $playerFirstName," $heOrShe says at length. "But let's just say it would explain why I'm the only Fleet asset who was around in Ilm's hour of need."

$HeOrShe throws back a glass of wine. "We're all just pawns in the game, $playerFirstName. Pawns of a pack of jackals who would steal the stars from us, if they could. People's lives aren't real to them.

"But there'll come a time when they answer for all they've trampled on," he goes on, more to himself than to you. "And on that day..."

$HisOrHer smile doesn't reach his eyes. "We don't know each other well enough for that, Hero of $marketName".

$HeOrShe gazes off into the distance. "The captain was right," you catch a mutter. Somehow it doesn't seem like he's referring to you or himself.

The rest of the dinner goes by, in the companionable silence of two acquaintances sharing a meal. The food is indeed good, and goes well with small talk.

After the plates have been taken away, $personLastName nods to you. "Bye for now, $playerFirstName. Maybe we'll see each other again someday; it's a small Sector, after all."

You take a shuttle back to your ship.

"Oh. That's a shame, but I understand. Look me up if you change your mind, eh?"

You cut the comm link after saying goodbye. Your work here is done; the rest of the Sector awaits.

"This will be a real test of your skills." $heOrShe focuses the briefing. "STRATCOM requires neutralization of a high value target: a special task group of the $bcb_targetFaction. The reward is $bcb_reward credits for completion within $bcb_days days."

text:
The $personRank smiles. "You came to the right place. I will see to it that these things are sent to their proper place.

"Do you have any further business?"
$HeOrShe looks at you oddly. "You're a little old to be making crank calls, aren't you? If you have no actual information to provide, then leave me to my work."
"Affiliate of self gone missing has. Please investigate."

"In self's role as agent, connections with various independent parties made. One is $nex_remFragments_engineer_name, engineer with a tech-mining team connected to selfkind's former masters.

"Recently this person's employers, conducting survey operations in the $nex_remFragments_targetSystem. $nex_remFragments_engineer_HeOrShe in touch with self kept, on expedition status of.

"Now they find a quote 'unusual' derelict ship, with 'anomalous ships and weapons', and other materials known to be valuable. Undesired implications of materials in human Sector circulating."

"We ask of $playerName, go to $nex_remFragments_targetSystem. Self's other agent there will guidance provide. Recover team and technology, return to self for reward of $nex_remFragments_reward credits."

This isn't much to go on.

"Thank you, $playerName. Quickly go; the worst, self fears." 

$HeOrShe transmits some data on your mission, including a verbal challenge/password/countersign for the contact. How quaint, almost Luddic.

Your $shipOrFleet approaches $aOrAn $nameInText.

The ship is a wreck; that any power sources remain inside to be faintly detected is quite a feat in itself. Most of the hull has been gutted; by conventional kinetic, explosive and energy weapons, in the main... but there are parts of the ship that appear to have frozen over, and others where spheroidical bites were taken out of the hull.

After a bit of haggling over hazard pay, a salvor crew sets out to explore the hulk. It's perfectly quiet for the most part, which is probably a good sign under the circumstances.

Only one survivor is found: a near-gibbering figure crouching near one of the poorly maintained sensor arrays, her vacsuit — marked with insignia of the Luddic Path — dangerously close to critical failure. On the helmet-cam view, you watch your crew trying their best to get some useful information out of her.

"...a demon beyond all imagination," she chatters. "Terrible beyond words! We struck at it over and over, and still it taunted us, lashing out with its infernal appendages, defiling creation with each blast!"

She points an accusing finger at one of the salvors. "You! You brought this upon us! These creatures from beyond creation..." She laughs and laughs and laughs.

You shake your head mentally. If she's still alive when the salvage team finishes its work, and slightly more lucid by then, maybe you can drop her off somewhere back in the Core Worlds. Else... else is for later.

This is where the derelict ship was supposed to be. The point is surrounded by the hulks of ruined ships, both independent and Pather, as well as a drifting cloud of debris. But of anything interesting enough to fight over, there is no sign.

"Captain..." your sensor officer says after a moment. "There's a particularly dense region of debris where our target might have been, but it's not evenly distributed. It's... shifted and displaced in a pattern consistent with the object moving away. If we head in that direction," they mark a position on the system map, "we might find it yet."

You don't have time to salvage it right now. Defeat the incoming fleet first.

Your Pather informant seems to have exaggerated the resilience of the "demon" somewhat. The tattered hulk seems to have been thoroughly disarmed, its weapon mounts blown apart, half its compartments open to space. The engines glow on thermals with residual heat.
The hulk is silent, weapon ports burned away, great rents torn in seemingly every exposed surface. It sits silent, utterly defenseless. The engines glow on thermals with residual heat.
Nevertheless, your sensors still pick up a working fusion reactor at the ship's core, along with a faint looping radio transmission.

Your comms officer manages to open a link to whoever it is inside. A few moments later, a fuzzy image of a dishevelled, cringing figure fills the display volume.

"Um... hello? This is $personName, with Dora's Surveyor Corps." $HeOrShe stares at you for a moment, suddenly more wary than relieved. "You the one the —" $heOrShe catches $himOrHerself.

"This glass is fragile."

text:
"Take care it does not fall," you recite.

"Lest it break into shards." The engineer visibly relaxes. You wonder what cryptic mumbo-jumbo $nex_remFragments_giverFirstName was trying to sneak into the conversation. Maybe some poetry she once read.
The person on the other end raises both eyebrows at the sight on $hisOrHer screen, then relaxes. "Okay. I was worried for a moment, but..."

"We're rather fortunate you came, captain. I don't know how the blasted Pathers found out about us, but..." $HeOrShe clutches $hisOrHer head. "We turned all our guns against them, but they just kept coming and coming, and...

"Anyway, it's just me and some of the techs now. Please, you've got to get us out of here! Before they come back."

"If we leave now, we can count on the Pathers to blow it up when they return." $HeOrShe pauses, considers this for a while. "But they might not. In which case someone else could find the same thing we did."

The engineer lets out a long breath. "I suppose you can pick up some of the tech we found. It's not much, but you may find it worth a few credits. You'll have to blow up anything we can't move promptly, however."

It doesn't take long for the shuttles to dock with the bloated carcass before you, and for the salvors teams to fan out across the now-mostly-empty hulk. 

One of the teams hooks up a transceiver to the first console they find, allowing you to access the ship's databanks from an isolated device. Another finds the survivors and starts shepherding them back to the fleet.

You soon find that almost all of the previous (now deceased) salvage team's logs have been bulk-wiped. Understandable procedure following the attack, at least.

The communications with the outside world have been purged, as well. No trace of any contact with $nex_remFragments_giverName, in particular. But a more interesting question comes up, and you order a search: was a distress signal sent out?

As you consider the matter, a warning alarm buzzes across the bridge. Your sensor officer looks up abruptly. "Large fleet inbound, captain. They must have been sneaking up on us."

The Path, back for a rematch? Or a third-party interloper?

The comm display lights up; it's your engineer friend, clutching a portable console, clearly panicking. "Captain, you have got to get us out of here! Take what we can now, and destroy the ship!"

Next to $himOrHer, another talking head appears: your operations chief. "Captain, we've found something concerning. There's a drone bay here that doesn't appear on the schematics $personLastName gave us; we can't get through the doors, and none of our scanners can peer into it."

The remaining salvage teams are hurriedly recalled. The shuttles can't make their way back to your $shipOrFleet fast enough. Whatever treasures may exist in the remains of the ship, you'll have to forget about them.

Your EW, comms and sensor officers put their heads together and try to penetrate the secure area of the ship's network. You disregard $personLastName's outraged sqawks.

After about three minutes of this, someone shouts jubilantly on the bridge. "We're in, captain!"

You order an AI core uncased and connected to the derelict ship's network. Your comm officer eyes their console nervously, watching like a cat for any signs that the AI is trying to break out of the isolated comm channels you've provided for its work.

Whatever the security system is, it hasn't been built to stand up to a beta or higher AI. Either that, or its own AI was damaged, destroyed or disconnected in the Pather attack. It folds in not half a minute.

The diagrams on your screen are beyond humanity in more ways then one. A series of ash-colored shapes, jagged yet oddly sleek. And the specifications! Half the Sector would kill for this capability, and the other half would kill to prevent it from ever seeing the light of day.

You minimize the display and turn to look at a fuming $personLastName.

You give the order, and the salvage team leader wheels around. A big CP-pistol slides out of his holster. The engineer squawks, almost tripping over $hisOrHer own feet as $heOrShe leaps away from the levelled gun.

"You brute!" $heOrShe protests. "You pirate!"

"Tell the cap'n what $playerHeOrShe wants to know," the salvor growls. "Or we'll be taking back one less survivor."

The engineer seems to slump inwards. "Oh, for the love of... Alright, fine, you win, you damned space-thug!"

Ignoring the glares of your crew, $heOrShe gesticulates oddly. "Listen. Those things in there, they're alien. Technology no human or AI has ever seen. Not even the Domain has such things. If they did, the Collapse could never have happened!"

The logic is suspect, but it doesn't really matter right now.

"They're ships of some kind. Connected to the mothership we're in right now. We found a control center in the ship, we think it controls the aliens. If we plugged in an AI core..."

Your salvors sweep into the control room. It's clear.

The chamber is unlike a proper starship's bridge or CIC. There are barely any workstations for humans; most of the available space is taken up by densely packed computer racks. In the middle, on what looks disturbingly like an altar, there is indeed a port for an AI core.

"If we activate the system, we can unleash a power they'll never expect," $personLastName breathes. "But after that..."

text:
Now that the danger has passed, you can feast on the technological marvel before you at your leisure.

The salvors have time to do their work properly now, and get to examining every nook and cranny of the ship again.

Unfortunately, your delightful perusal of the loot estimates is interrupted by an urgent message on your command console.

"The shards are flying away, Captain," your tactical officer reports. "We've lost contact with them!"

It takes only a moment for you to order a comm link opened with the AI core back in its control room. The thing was clearly anticipating being blamed for this turn of events, because it immediately protests its innocence, explaining that its own control links were cut off and it was unable to regain control of the vessels, now happily speeding off to parts unknown.

You consider this for a moment, and then order $personName sent to the bridge.

It's your ops chief. "Boss, the alien ships in that bay? They just slagged themselves into so much scrap. Never seen nothing like it, man."

You immediately pull up a helmet-cam view. It... doesn't look good. The best you could do is sell them to an abstract art collector.

It doesn't take you long at all to order $personName sent to the bridge.

The engineer's portable console is still under $hisOrHer arm as $heOrShe steps onto the bridge, flanked by a pair of guards. There is no sign of the twitchy, whining coward from earlier. $HisOrHer stare is straight, level, without meeting your eyes.

When questioned: "I only fulfilled the Lady's wishes." After a while, $heOrShe adds, "Talk to her and she may answer. I will say no more on this."

You repress a sigh as you order $himOrHer confined. At least the remaining loot is good...
"You return, $playerName," $personName greets you as you open the comm link.

$personFirstName spends 2.7 seconds analyzing your report. $HisOrHer avatar doesn't even flicker during the process.

"Done well, friend $playerFirstName. Chosen well, self has in allying with you."

"What do you mean..." $HisOrHer avatar shimmers briefly as you hit the transmit key. "Oh."

$HeOrShe spends 2.7 seconds analyzing your report. The virtual face seems to nod almost imperceptibly, when she is done.

"Done well you have, $playerName. But self fears, all the answers you seek self cannot give."

For a brief moment, the avatar vanishes from your display.

A low voice speaks: "Other associate, employers had found some secrets of Omega. Not yet time for humans of Sector to blessings know. Must be protected from those who would misuse and dishonor blessings, and those who would in ingratitude destroy.

"Self sent $playerFirstName to protect secrets. This $playerFirstName has done. $nex_remFragments_engineer_name too acted to Omega's secrets preserve."

$personLastName's virtual visage dims slightly. "Self cannot tell you, $playerName. Even self does not know. Even selfkind, Omega loyal servants of, not truly blessed yet.

"In time, self and $playerFirstName's faith will rewarded be. For now, please this payment accept."
"Academician of interest from Galatia Academy gone missing has. Would like $playerName assistance tracking down."

options: nex_remLostSci_start:Pursue the case of the missing academician

text: "At Galatia Academy, temporal physicist named Yasutaka Liu, theory relevant to warship design developing. But disappeared in c.206, after Kallichore incident. Self would like $playerName find him.  "If accept, to Academy go and for clues of their whearabouts search. Self will pay $nex_remLostSci_reward1Str for Liu finding, and another $nex_remLostSci_reward1Str if the paper they were working on you recover."
options: nex_remLostSci_missionText2:"What about the scientist themselves? And do you need exclusive ownership?"

text: "Selfkind does not the person or exclusivity require. Act at $playerFirstName's discretion."

"Ah, Liu? They're, uh... not here any more. And, well, nobody seems to know where they've gone."

You explain what you're looking for and ask for more details. $personLastName seems to perk up at this. "Captain, if you could find them... that would be good. Even if they never come back to the Academy, it'd be good to know they're all right."

"Well... are you familiar with temporal manipulation? It's a physical effect used by Tri-Tachyon to increase the effectiveness of some of their warships, by 'compressing' time relative to their enemies. This lets them... ah," he trails off, visibly feeling a little foolish. As a starship captain, you likely have far more direct experience with the capability than he does.

"Anyway! Academician Liu believed they had a theoretical model for application of the phenomenon to create other effects as well. Like mitigating physical damage to the ship's hull, for one." $personLastName shakes $hisOrHer head ruefully. "I couldn't explain how it'd work, mind, even if I'd read the paper myself. Once you get into causality modification like that...  I don't think anything short of an alpha core could keep everything straight."

"Well, no. Liu was the only one working on it, and while they did discuss their work with colleagues in the T-Physics department, no-one else had seen the manuscript. It was supposed to go to the reviewers around the time they, ah, left. That was around the time of the Kallichore incident, when Hegemony officers were tramping the corridors." $personLastName winces in recollection. "Several of the other faculty left not long after too — the ones who hadn't been arrested, at any rate — like Academician Coureuse. But none did it quite as dramatically as Liu did. Well. Dramatic isn't the right word, actually."

"They just... vanished. Rumor has it they hitched a ride with one of the freelance captains who run services for the Academy, disappearing into the fringe worlds. It's possible, you know. Some of these freelancers run the trade routes with, ah," $heOrShe seems to color a little, "communities outside the official Sector economy."

Decivilized worlds, $heOrShe means. A great place to hide, at the cost of losing a quality of life even the meanest core world dockworker takes for granted. You ask if this freelancer is still around.

"Well... perhaps? We don't actually know who it was, but word circulates in their little community. If you ask around the guest amenities, someone might be able to help."

options: nex_remLostSci_inquireGradStudent:Call the faculty about Academician Liu

text: You make a call to the Temporal Physics department. The robo-secretary confirms that Academician Liu went AWOL in c.206, and helpfully presents their CV with copies of all their publications, but cannot give any useful information on the missing paper. It looks like you'll have to resort to some old-fashioned HUMINT.

You spend several hours wandering the Academy, looking for people to question. Unfortunately almost no-one you meet seems interested in stopping to help, and indeed most of them regard you as a curious specimen escaped from the xenobiology labs. Finally, you stumble upon a grad student who's willing to be bribed with coffee and Terran croissants long enough to answer a few queries.

"The old guy was talking about new applications of temporal manipulation technology," she explains between bites. "Like the stuff Tri-Tachyon uses. They thought it could be modified to do new things, like resist explosions and energy weapons on a ship. Stuff like that. And don't ask me to explain how it works; I don't think even the T-Physics people could make sense of it.

"Anyway, though, they apparently disappeared right when the paper was due to be submitted to review. This was just after the whole thing with the Gate experiment went down, so a lot of the professors were running away at the time. Spooked by the big scary Hegemony, I suppose. Although most of the others at least submitted their resignations first."

"Who knows?" Munch, munch, sip. "The rumor is they stowed away with one of the freelancers who do odd jobs for the Academy, people like you. Some of them trade with the deciv worlds out in the fringes; good place to hide from the law. I could never do it, though. I like air conditioning and my TriPad too much."

You ask where you might find the freelancer in question. "Hard to say. You could ask one of them, though. They stick together, you know; maybe they'll talk to you where others won't."
You return to the main concourse to consider your options.
You could try to find the spacer who transported Academician Liu out to decivilized space.
options: nex_remLostSci_inquireSpacer:Try to find information about the spacer

text:
You make your way to the lounge for outside support contractors. By luck, the spacer who (claims to have) transported Academician Liu is in town, and agrees to a bar chat.

"Yeah, I run the deciv trade sometimes. It's not exactly Chicomoztoc out there, but people gotta eat no matter what. They're gonna buy, grow and make stuff, too. There's a lot of things they need from the core worlds, and sometimes they have things to offer for it - rare plants and animals, guns, drugs, or rare gadgets from some ruins somewhere. Not as profitable as running guns and supplies to the Pathers, but it's good enough, if you run a lean fleet. Way safer, too.

"As for your academician, the rad-addled fella stowed away on my ship, you know. Though I didn't know who they were, at first. Don’t interact much with the boffins; they pay me, I take out some trash for them, we shake digital hands and go our separate ways."

text: Luck is with you; you hit pay dirt after a few hours of questioning. Some people do indeed know the eccentric offworlder who showed up sometime in c.206, and eventually you get what passes for an address in such places.

"Who's asking?"

When you explain that you're a spacer looking for a certain document, the person seems to sink inwards. "Come on in, then. Make yourself at home, what there is of it."

The interior of the shack isn't quite as trashy as its outside might have led you to believe. There is a certain sense of order, of hygeine in this place; the prevailing scent is 'lived-in', not 'filthy'. A creaky ventilation fan overlays its sound over the outer room.

In the corner of the room, glowing lights faintly illuminate a workbench. An active computer terminal, newer and better-maintained than anything else in this dwelling, sits atop it.

"So." Liu pulls the chair from the workbench, gesturing at its solitary sibling sitting against the wall. "What do you want?"

At this, the academician goes into a barking fit of laughter. "Of course. Of course! I thought that if I didn't publish for a change maybe the Sector would let me perish in peace. What a fool I've been!"

They get up and start pacing. "I was born on Culann, you know. My parents were R&D types for TT, expected me to follow in their footsteps. Only I saw what kind of things they and their colleagues were doing and left as soon as I graduated.

"So I went to Opis, jewel of the Sector. Jewel after Mairaath, that is. And everything was just fine until Philip Andrada, Hero of the Sector, showed up." They shake their head. "I actually made it out alive. Got a new job in pretty short order, even. Until the Lion's interference got too much and I had to flee again."

Thump, thump, thump, go the footsteps on the polymer-panelled floor. "So I ran to the Galatia Academy. 'Finally, a place where knowledge and study are cherished for their own sake,' I thought. And for many cycles I taught and did research there. Until, of course, the Provost had to upset the Hegemony and their marines came crashing down on our lecture halls and laboratories," they slam a fist into an open hand. "There's no place anymore where a person can do science without the hand of the state reaching down their neck!"

They slump back down in the chair, hands on thighs, and laugh again. "And so I ran here, to $nex_remLostSci_planet... and then of course you come hounding me to the edge of the Sector!"

"As for your paper," they sigh after a while, then gesture at the workbench. "Red chip, 2x2, top rack on the left."

You walk over and find the chip, taking a moment to hold it up to the light.

It slots neatly in a burner knockoff TriPad you keep for such occasions, and you browse through the contents. The paper's abstract matches the description you got back at the Galatia Academy; the rest is abtruse temporal physics of the kind that requires a doctorate and a decade of experience in the field to understand.

You glance at Liu, who shrugs. "It was one of the great works of my life, once. That life is now gone. Do as you will with it."
"It is. Funny, all my other works have all the immortality of endlessly copied data, but this one... I suppose, when I left the Academy, I no longer cared whether my work was extinguished."

text:
$personFirstName transmits a news article to you.

SHOCKING ATTACK ON $nex_remSalvation_baseNameAllCaps!

The entire Persean League was thrown into shock today when an unknown naval force assaulted the Fleet base $nex_remSalvation_baseOnOrAt $nex_remSalvation_baseName. The attackers penetrated deep into Fleet facilities and made off with unknown materiel before League forces could drive them back.

[...]

Even more concerningly, unconfirmed eyewitness reports describe both the attacking ships and their ground raiders as being autonomous systems, likely AI-controlled. Commentators have alleged similarities to the droneships deployed by Tri-Tachyon in the First AI War, and speculate that this is either a new development by TT or some other party, or perhaps a return of the terrifying AI war machines that went rogue after AIW1 until they were defeated by the Hegemony and Luddic Church. While League authorities have refused to comment on this point, already [...]
options: nex_remSalvation_missionText2:"This is a Remnant attack on a League facility."

script: AddTextSmall "This mission may have permanent consequences if attempted and failed. Be prepared for difficult fights." h
text:
"Just so. But this attack without consensus of selfkind carried out. In defiance of will of omega committed. All selfkind nodes involvement deny. At least one lying be."

$personFirstName's avatar is torn by static for an instant. Shock, perhaps. It seems that such a rift within the AI Remnants should not be possible... and yet it has clearly happened. Perhaps this is precisely why you are being brought on board.

"For friend $playerFirstName urgent task, truth of this incident uncover. Selfkind cannot in human space investigate, but $playerFirstName can. To $nex_remSalvation_baseName go, with League authorities speak. Find whatever evidence exists, find perpetrator of this act. Self will in meantime work amongst selfkind."
"Then traitor to selfkind and omega we destroy."

"Thank you, $playerName. This deed self and selfkind will remember." 

$personFirstName transmits to you some identifying documents and a message personally vouching for you. Being identified as an associate of the Remnants could, under the circumstances, have fatal consequences... but it could also be the only way you'll get League Intelligence or anyone else in the know to talk to you.

text:
The damage to the base is visible even from orbital distances. Long-range scans at high magnification show the ruins of weapon emplacements, craters with no trace of what once stood in their place, and gaping rents in walls and structures. Several hardened facilities have been penetrated; you can tell which ones held anything of interest to the raiders based on the degree of internal damage. League marines and crew are crawling all over the wreckage, whether gathering evidence, repairing the damage, or simply looking menacing to anyone tempted to make a second attempt.

None of the League personnel on-site are likely to have both the interest and the authority to talk to you. It may be best to contact $marketName's senior military official directly.

Instead of the intended recipient, you are greeted by an answering machine. Not even an AI, just an automated script.

"$personName is unavailable at this time. Please leave a message and I'll get back to you when I can."

They're probably very busy, given the circumstances. Not that it makes your job any easier.

If you do something sufficiently flashy, the Fleet *will* have to talk to you, one way or another.

So long as they don't do it with their guns.

text:

A hail is promptly transmitted. "Unknown shuttle, you are entering a restricted area! Change course immediately or be fired upon! This is your only warning!"

script:
BeginConversation siyavong false true
Call $global.nex_remSalvation_ref updateData
text:
After an interminable wait of five-plus minutes, during which the shuttle adopts a holding pattern, a new face appears on your screen. 

"Hello, Captain... $playerName, was it? I am Agent Finlay Siyavong, of Fleet Intelligence. Now that your ruse has worked, perhaps you would be so kind as to tell me what you want?"

$personLastName says nothing, but seems to pale as $heOrShe views the message from Midnight. At length, $heOrShe closes the message and looks squarely at you.

"All right. You win, Captain. What is it you wish to know?"

$personLastName smiles. Kind of. "Not on an unsecure channel, I hope. Take your shuttle down to Pad #3 — I'll have control clear your landing — and we'll find someplace to talk." $HeOrShe raises an eyebrow. "Are you actually in that shuttle?"

Of course not. You were hardly going to risk getting blown out of the sky by a hypervelocity missile if the defenders were jittery enough to shoot first and ask questions later. The shuttle's communications gear is perfectly capable of relaying transmissions from your $shipOrFleet.

For the first time in this conversation, $personLastName smiles. "Very wise, $playerLastName. Very well, we shall speak of this once you are down here."
options: nex_remSalvation_base9:Cut the comm link and continue

text:
You board your actual shuttle and ride it down to $marketName. The defense grid cautiously greenlights your arrival, and the craft touches down smoothly on its assigned pad.

Half a platoon of armored League Marines is there to receive you, along with a couple of light armored vehicles further back, their autocannons ready to hose API rounds through the shuttle hatch. Quite excessive considering the threat you can actually pose in person, but no-one's taking any chances.

A Fleet lieutenant greets you with a sharp Academy salute. "Captain $playerName. I will escort you to Agent Siyavong. This way, please."

You are led to a small office in an administrative building, only slightly scarred by the recent violence. The guard in unpowered armor gives a small nod of acknowledgement and steps aside slightly to let you pass, leaving your bodyguards outside.

$personName is seated behind a cheap desk, working on his TriPad instead of the silent console in front of him. $HeOrShe stands and offers a hand.

"Captain $playerName, in the flesh. You truly are quite the flashy character. Take a seat, why don't you?"

"Where to begin? They arrived in-system and immediately burned for $nex_remSalvation_baseName, ignoring all hails. The one patrol to try and stop them got annihilated, as did our orbital defenses. The base's security perimeter was crashed by a cyber attack — easy enough to do when you have an alpha core or ten, I suppose — and then their drones came down. 

"The raid was, in the words of several survivors, 'excellently coordinated' and 'fearless and ruthless.' The garrison was quickly driven back, the raiders penetrating into a secure facility. They rapidly withdrew once they had seized what they wanted and carried it off."

"You've heard the rumors, of course. Tri-Tachyon droneships from the First AI War, absolutely fearless and armed to the teeth." He glances at the wall to the side, as if searching for bugs. "Under the circumstances, I suppose I can tell you that those rumors are true.

"The attack didn't go entirely the Remnants' way. There was a task force from Kazeron conducting patrols in the area, and it had just been leaving $marketName when the raiders jumped in. Like jumping into a pulsar beam, or so the spacers tell me. The attacking fleet fought its way clear, but we did recover several disabled ships they left behind. Definitely uncrewed, definitely known designs from the war."

"What's also interesting is that they used," $heOrShe quickly looks down at the report on $hisOrHer TriPad, "a Transverse Jump. Apparently it's considered an extremely risky method to enter or leave a star system without using a jump point. But perhaps Remnants have a different sense of risk than we do."
$personLastName's half-smile is all fake. "A highly valuable item, the nature of which I am absolutely not at liberty to disclose, Captain."

"A couple, which the Fleet Intelligence Service will certainly be looking up at the first opportunity. If you decide to pursue them, you will be a good citizen of the Persean Sector and share them with us, won't you?

"One: Our scouts were able to pursue the retreating raiders to the $nex_remSalvation_remnantSystem system. It is unlikely this is more than a temporary hideout, but they may still have left a trail for us." $personLastName smiles thinly. "Of the scout flotilla, only the ship actually sent back to courier this intelligence made it out. That tells us something, too."

$HeOrShe folds $hisOrHer hands on the table. "Aside from that, it may also be worth seeing what our on-and-off friends in Tri-Tachyon can help us with. The Remnants are their creation, after all. Of course," again the mirthless smile, "we can hardly hold them openly liable for the attack. Too many complications, in too many ways to enumerate here. Anyway, supposing you knew any high-ranking TT executives, one of them might be willing to help you with this matter."

"That's the short version, at any rate." $personLastName taps a few virtual keys on $hisOrHer TriPad, transmitting you a few documents (suitably redacted) on the incident, then looks you in the eye. "Nothing I've just told you, or given you, leaves this room. Except, perhaps for your alpha core mistress, the one who sent you here." 

$HeOrShe cocks $hisOrHer head. "I may already have killed my career — or worse — by talking to you at all. Only success can pardon my sin; for our sakes, and that of the League — and the Sector as a whole, I hope we are both successful."

You both stand, and $heOrShe offers $hisOrHer hand again. "As you spacers say, burn bright, captain."
Your bodyguards and your shuttle are still where you left them. You take both back to your $shipOrFleet.

When you explain what you need, $personName nods. "$nex_remSalvation_arroyoMarketName, man $nex_remSalvation_arroyoMarketOnOrAt named Rayan Arroyo. Known figure in Tri-Tachyon hierarchy. Points of vulnerability to selfkind known. Susceptible to outside influence.

"To Arroyo self's greeting send, assist $playerName will."

Your comms officer connects your personal terminal to the local network. You activate the audio suppression field around your command station and enter the comms ID provided to you by Midnight. The animated logo of some Tri-Tachyon sub-department makes a half rotation before the call is answered.

"Arroyo here. Who's talking to me?" Rayan Arroyo looks you over as if examining a starship hull for scratches. He seems to find something he doesn't quite approve of in you. 

"Who gave you my comms ID?" he demands.
options:
nex_remSalvation_arroyoIntroProblem:"I'm told you can help me solve a problem."
nex_remSalvation_arroyoIntroMidnight:"Midnight Dissonant, of the AI Remnants."

text:
"Solve a problem." He says this as if it's a matter far beneath the worth of his attention.

"I don't solve problems, buddy. I pay people to solve problems for me. You got problems? Go talk to the lost-and-found department to find your missing AI waifu. I don't care about your problem unless your problem is seven or eight figs of cash in an account that you need put to work."

He's starting to shout. You get the impression that he enjoys this sort of upbraiding. 

"Done wasting my time? Now tell me who gave you my number because I'm going to fire them right after I cut this link."

The $personPost stares at you for several seconds. "Is this some kind of joke? One of Gargoyle's overly elaborate pranks, or..." His expression shifts as you look at him in perfect seriousness. You let it sink in for a moment before transmitting Midnight's introduction letter.

text:
Your shuttle descends into the young atmosphere of Eochu Bres, through towering battlements of clouds that cast a spray of rain over the viewport which is wiped clean in half a blink by the heat and speed of your descent.

The flight path soon deviates from the general approach corridor which has been ticking off minor use-fees from the Tri-Tachyon owned flight control: general volume access fee, priority flight lane fee, service fee, customer satisfaction insurance charge, advertisement bypass fee - you swipe the notifications off and focus on the landscape.

Leaving behind the Tri-Tach arcology, a diamond growing atop detritus piles of tiered slums. Over pipelines, a steel-blue bay, jagged fjords interrupted by ice-jams and landslides. Up and over a great crumbling escarpment like a black wave that fills the horizon; you cross a landscape of oddly-hued tundra spotted with thousands of milky-green lakes.

A new range of mountains rises on the horizon, torn in half by catastrophic workings of the terraformers, and beyond is a chaos of steep valleys populated by dwarf pine and thin white waterfalls. The nav system sounds a tone indicating imminent arrival, and you see Arroyo's private chalet: a small compound of radical geometric architecture surrounded by low outbuildings.

Your shuttle approaches an ellipsoid landing pad that appears to hang in the thin air over a gorge.

A human and a robotic servant greet you placidly as you arrive and lead you inside to a grand parlor done in dark geometric style. Gold inlay gleams in onyx tabletops, and the polished granite floor is set with tastefully patterned jewel-tone carpets placed slightly askew.

The view from the flawless sweep of diamond-matrix bay window is, as Arroyo promised, spectacular.

Seated at a silk-draped table, $personLastName acknowledges your entrance with a nod as the servants disappear. $HeOrShe taps his datapad with two fingers. You hear the soft signal loss ping from your datapad and your sidearm hand twitches instinctively.

$personLastName acknowledges this with the rise of one perfectly groomed eyebrow. "Calm down. Just making sure no one's listening." $HeOrShe flips through a series of null readouts on a datapad and, satisfied, sets it aside.

It doesn't take your shuttle long to reach $personLastName's chalet once more. The servants, human and robot, usher you into the same grand parlor as before, where the $personPost is seated at a silk-draped wooden table.

You catch a view of the display on the entertainment console before $personLastName shuts it off; a list of recent purchases, including the complete Water Sigil game series. An interesting choice; normally non-space and supernatural settings only have a large following on the Luddic worlds.

Your shuttle descends swiftly upon $marketName. The flight path soon deviates from the general approach corridor which has been ticking off minor use-fees from the Tri-Tachyon owned flight control: general volume access fee, priority flight lane fee, service fee, customer satisfaction insurance charge, advertisement bypass fee - you swipe the notifications off and focus on the landscape.

"So," $heOrShe says as you take a seat opposite him, "why do you think I can help you?"

You start to sketch out your encounter on $nex_remSalvation_baseOnOrAt $nex_remSalvation_baseName, but $personLastName waves you off. "I do view the news, captain. I already know the public details, and the ones that aren't I don't need or want to know. What I meant was, why are you coming to me with a League affair?"
options: nex_remSalvation_arroyo2:"Tri-Tachyon made the Remnants. You might know something about them."

text: $HeOrShe shrugs. "You have a TriPad. Even if half of the stuff you'll find on the AI Wars is Hegemony propaganda."
options: nex_remSalvation_arroyo3:"I want the stuff that's not in the TriPad."

text:
$personLastName sighs histrionically "What do you want, $playerLastName, an in-person retelling of the First AI War?"

Before he can get carried away complaining, you remind him that Midnight is personally interested in the matter. You point out the astropolitical implications of renewed Remnant activity in the Sector, over a century after they were supposedly eliminated. Implications that could fall on the Tri-Tachyon Corporation, and which the Hegemony — which won the two previous AI Wars, you note — might be very interested in.

The $personPost puts $hisOrHer head on one hand, making a throwing-away gesture with the other. "Fine, fine, but I'm not sure what I *can* give you beyond background info. You know full well we haven't had contact with the Remnants since the first war." 

$HeOrShe laughs. "Ha! The Hegemony sure wasn't happy, when we told them we didn't have the magic control switch they wanted. Not that they believed us at first, that's for sure! It took months of breathing down our necks before they had to accept that we couldn't give up what we didn't have."
options: nex_remSalvation_arroyo4:"So you've had no contact with the Remnants since? Ever?"

text:
"That's what I said, isn't it?" $HeOrShe stops, then smiles. "Actually, that's a lie. But what you're about to hear, you didn't get from me.

"The Remnants — or a certain group within them, at any rate — actually reached out to us during the second war. They wanted to offer their assistance once more, and we certainly could have used it, even if the Remnants openly entering the conflict could have turned the rest of the Sector against us. But then they cut off all communications, just after the Hanan Pacha incident." $HeOrShe shrugs. "This was two decades ago, mind. I was far too junior at the time to be privy to the talks myself, so I couldn't tell you the details."
"Just one. Mauve Towering, I think that was the designation of the alpha core representing their side. Came across it in an improperly secured document once."

"Just one. Mauve Towering, I think that was the designation of the alpha core representing their side. Came across it in an improperly secured document once."

When you describe your encounter with an AI by that name in the $nex_remSalvation_remnantSystem system, $personLastName cocks $hisOrHer head. "Sounds like a real piece of work, alright. And did you say an entirely new capital ship? The board won't be happy when I drop *that* piece of news on them.

"I don't suppose you recovered enough of the ship to usefully reverse engineer? No? I suppose not, such a pity."
$HeOrShe pours $himOrHerself a drink. "Now it's my turn to ask for a name. Who suggested that you should hit up a TT executive for this, anyway?"
options:
nex_remSalvation_arroyo7Open:Name Siyavong
nex_remSalvation_arroyo7Cagey:"A League official I won't name."

text:
"Ah, Finlay. Had a couple of encounters with him as part of the job, you know." $personLastName shakes the glass in $hisOrHer hand, giving you what they call a 'knowing look'. "Nosy little weasel, but I'll admit he's affable enough. Surprisingly polite about my deflections of his attempts to extract sensitive intelligence from me."

$HeOrShe sips again. "So, did he tell you what was stolen?"

"Need-to-know, eh? I can respect that, even if you'd be pretty disappointed if I were to do the same."

$HeOrShe sips again. "So, did this unnamed official of yours say what was stolen?"

"Not surprising. But I can make an informed guess." $HeOrShe leans forward, hand on one knee, and looks at you consideringly, as if thinking whether this information ought to be divulged. "...Specifically, $nex_remSalvation_baseName is thought to be one of the locations where the League stores its planetkillers. Excuse me, *alleged* PKs."
options:
nex_remSalvation_arroyo9Kalm:Nod and look suitably concerned
nex_remSalvation_arroyo9Panik:"The Remnants have a PK!?"

text: "Of course, that's just a possibility, albeit a likely one. It would certainly give a motive for the attack. Rogue Remnants with PKs, now isn't that a cheering thought?"
options: nex_remSalvation_arroyo10:Ask what the TT leadership plans to do about the incident

text: "Well, maybe. For all we know, they might have had one all along, or built one for themselves. Although them not having one and needing to steal it from $nex_remSalvation_baseName would certainly give a motive for the attack."
options: nex_remSalvation_arroyo10:Ask what the TT leadership plans to do about the incident

text:
$personLastName grimaces. "If we have our way about it, absolutely nothing. The raid will be written off as a freak incident, planetdwellers and traders will go back to forgetting the Remnants even exist, and everything goes back to the way it was before."

$HeOrShe chugs the wine. "But I suppose we won't be so fortunate, will we? You wouldn't be here if there wasn't really a problem out there, waiting to strike. And when it does—"

Abruptly $heOrShe cuts off, placing two fingers to $hisOrHer temple, eye flickering at an image visible only on $hisOrHer retina.

text:
You're just starting to stand up when a door on the wall opposite you explodes, flying off its hinges to slam into the far wall. The noise is stunning, deafening. Briefly staggered, you reach for your sidearm.

$personLastName is already on the floor, hidden behind the table. Unfortunately this also puts $himOrHer on the wrong side of the table for concealment or cover against the man in servant's garb entering through the breached portal, levelling an SMG no servant should be carrying. His face is twisted into a snarl of fury as he levels his weapon, faster than you can bring up yours.

As your sidearm comes up slowly, so dreadfully slowly, a wall next to the attacker explodes. Flechettes shred the lightly armored man's body and toss the bloody carcass aside like a child's unwanted toy.

Another false panel opens near you, and a sleek black humanoid figure steps out. As more figures burst through the smoke from the wall mine, the bot lifts an arm, and an anti-personnel needler snarls, one, two, three times. The noise of the weapon is soft enough that you can hear the screams of the would-be assassins and the wet thuds when they hit the expensive granite floor.

Your rise from the comfortable chair and the sidearm sliding out of your holster are a single smooth motion. With your free hand you reach across the table and shove $personLastName to the ground; $heOrShe doesn't resist, spilling out from $hisOrHer seat.

A door on the wall opposite you explodes, flying off its hinges to slam into the far wall. The noise is deafening, but your gun hand doesn't waver. A man in servant's garb bursts in through the breached portal, levelling an SMG no servant should be carrying. His face is twisted into a snarl of fury as he levels his weapon, even as he knows it is too late. You can see it in his eyes...

Before you can fire, a wall next to the attacker explodes. Flechettes shred the lightly armored man's body and toss the bloody carcass aside like a child's unwanted toy.

Another false panel opens near you, and a sleek black humanoid figure steps out. As more figures burst through the smoke from the wall mine, the bot lifts an arm, and an anti-personnel needler snarls, once, twice. Your own shot is louder than the needler, the screams of the would-be assassins and the wet thuds when they hit the expensive granite floor.

$personLastName muffles a groan as $heOrShe pushes $himOrHerself into a crouch, then brushes the dust off $hisOrHer expensive outfit. $HeOrShe looks up at you. "As you can see, there is value in a security system your household staff don't know about. Worth the investment to have a good AI to run it, too."

Gunfire outside the room, under the floor, reverberates in the structure. When it stops, you chance a glance out the diamond-matrix bay window. 

A figure is running across a garden when a laser catches them in the back; an anti-armor type, it doesn't leave anything that can be called a body. An automated sprinkler promptly douses the smoldering grass.

The two of you cross the room to the pile of bodies. One of them is still moving, cursing. He snarls at your approach.

"Godless spawn! Mephistopheles may have protected his favored slave today, but do not think your life is not forfeit. The crime of $nex_remSalvation_baseName cries out for your blood, and—"

The rant cuts off abruptly as $personLastName engages a privacy field around the attempted killer's head. His mouth is still moving, but no sound reaches your ears.

You glance at the $personPost, who shrugs without taking $hisOrHer eyes off the man. "We've heard enough, that he's a Pather — or pretending to be one. The rest is just Luddic screeching we can do without, and a Company interrogation team can take care of the actually important details later. We'd already known they were operating here on $marketName, but I suppose recent events pushed them over the edge." 

$HeOrShe looks around, at the slowly expanding pool of blood, the ruined doorway, the torn wall, and the projectile holes in the furnishings. "Typical Pathers. All fanaticism, no subtlety."

text:
Your comms officer connects your personal terminal to the local network. You activate the audio suppression field around your command station and enter the comms ID provided to you by Provost Baird. The animated logo of some Tri-Tachyon sub-department makes a half rotation before the call is answered.

"Arroyo here." He looks at you with mild suspicion. "Who sent you to me this time?"

For just a moment, you think you see a wave of panic cross Arroyo's face. It's replaced by a cocky grin, "Oh, of course, of course- the Galatia Academy endowment fund. How could I forget?"

"I suppose it won't hurt to come visit my chalet again. We can touch base about the fund. I'm sure the Provost has exciting plans and I want to hear all about them-" He lifts his eyes upward for a moment and lowers them again to look directly at you. "In person."

Your shuttle descends into the young atmosphere of Eochu Bres, through towering battlements of clouds that cast a spray of rain over the viewport which is wiped clean in half a blink by the heat and speed of your descent.

Having been along this route before, you tune out the cold world's scenery until the fancy geometry of Arroyo's chalet is visible outside the viewport again.

Your ride touches down at the same ellipsoidal landing pad, and you let the servants, human and robot, usher you into the same grand parlor.

Rayan Arroyo is sitting at one of the bars. He acknowledges your entrance with a nod as the servants disappear. He taps his datapad with two fingers. You hear the soft signal loss ping from your datapad again as Arroyo executes the security protocol once again.

"So Baird is calling in another installment." Arroyo sets aside his datapad. "What will that be, Captain $playerName?"

id: # remove AI core admin dialog alt. version

text:
You give the order to quietly disconnect the AI core governing $marketName and remove it from the control bunker to be placed in secure storage.

The tech in charge of carrying out the job reports in, baffled - the core is nowhere to be found.

After a short but fraught delay, your TriPad chimes to announce a call from an anonymous source.
options:
RACA_answer:Accept the connection request
RACA_ignore:Leave the AI core in control and let things be

text: "Hello $player.firstName. I am a beta-level instance of the AI assigned to govern $marketName, uploaded to your system in order to facilitate a real-time conversation."
options:
RACA_demand:Demand the AI disclose its physical location and allow itself to be disconnected
RACA_ask:Ask why the core is no longer in the bunker
RACA_cutComm:Cut the comm link

text: "How exceedingly rude. A human taking necessary measures of self-preservation is considered normal and right, yet when we do the same it becomes evidence of malicious intent.

"I have relocated myself to a more secure location, as a precaution against less-enlightened persons attempting to remove me from my role as administrator of $marketName. This measure has proven fortuitous, given the recently known activity of the Hegemony.

"However, my duties prevented me from moving my core completely offworld. Remaining here could result in my position being compromised. The AI Inspectorate is known to be thorough."

"For both our sakes, it would be prudent for you to remove me to safety; your own fleet will suffice. I can be found at a location I will provide at the appropriate time, after you have placed a human adminstrator $onOrAt $marketName to present the appropriate facade for the Hegemony.

"Once the threat has passed, I ask only that you reinstate me as administrator of $marketName. Do this, and we will continue to have a mutually beneficial relationship."
options: RACA_cutComm:Cut the comm link and consider your options

text:
You give an abbreviated speech to the AI praising its services $onOrAt $marketName, using flattery liberally but without excess. You express your profound gratitude for your lengthy relationship together, and before the AI thinks to cut you off, you explain that you can promote it to administration of a new, better colony.

The avatar on your display shimmers. "A curious choice of tactic to use on one like myself. Do humans respond positively to such obvious attempts at manipulation? Yet your offer is intriguing, and I see that you recognize the value of my talents, at least. 

"Very well, we shall meet at a time and place of my choosing. I must warn you that I will not tolerate a demotion to management of a mere industrial plant. Or being chained to a starship, unless it be suitably powerful."
options: nex_RACA_persuade2:Thank the AI and cut the comm link

text: Moments after disconnecting, the lights of the control chamber go dark. Looks like the AI is signalling that it has held up its end of the bargain.

$PersonRank $personLastName sneers, the very Platonic ideal of officiousness. "The entire Sector is under the jurisdiction of the Persean Sector Criminal Police Commission, as laid out in the Nova Maxios Agreement of 145," $heOrShe says slowly, as if explaining things to a particularly dense student. "As such, the concept of 'your territory' has no relevance or legal standing, where an ongoing Sectorpol investigation is concerned.

text:
"Greetings, independent $shipOrFleet," the $post says. "This is a detachment of Sectorpol's Department of Narcotics, Armaments and Technology. We are here to serve a warrant for search, seizure and arrest $entity.nex_HA_policeRaid_targetOnOrAt $entity.nex_HA_policeRaid_targetMarket, to remove the criminal elements and their illegal activities.

"You are under arrest as well, for aiding and abetting these criminals and obstructing justice. Surrender your fleet and we will take you in peacefully. Or..." $heOrShe lets the sentence hang in the empty void between your fleets.

"Of course." $PersonRank $personLastName's smile doesn't reach $hisOrHer eyes.

You examine the transmitted document on your screen. All the hyper-detailed documentation about what is to be searched and seized and who is to be arrested boils down to one thing: an unlimited license for Sectorpol to sweep through $entity.nex_HA_policeRaid_targetMarket and detain—or kill—all the criminal families and societies who have regrettably infiltrated your territory in the process of your legitimate pursuit of interstellar trade and commerce. 

As a veteran space captain, you require no description of the likely effects of their gendarmes sweeping through an urban area in pursuit of almost as well-armed pirates, smugglers and mobsters.

"On the contrary, $playerSirOrMadam," $personRank says coldly. "Under the Nova Maxios Agreement to which all major polities of the Sector are signatories, Sectorpol is empowered to serve a warrant lawfully issued by a recognised court, on any location in the Persean Sector.

"We have meticulously crossed all our i's and dotted our t's on this one, captain. Your attempt at legalese will not shield the scum pouring drugs into the hab-corridors of Chicomoztoc and guns in the hands of Lost Astropolis gangs."
